results.name: Square array, read by antidiagonals, where row n+1 is generated from row n by first removing terms in row n at positions {floor(m*(m+7)/6), m>=0} and then taking partial sums, starting with all 1's in row 0.
comment: A variant of the triple factorial array A136212. Compare to triangle array A136218, which is generated by a complementary process.
formula: Let triangular matrix P = A136220, then: column 0 (A136221) = column 0 of P; column 1 (A136226) = column 0 of P^2; column 3 (A136229) = column 0 of P^4.
example: where terms in parenthesis are at positions {floor(m*(m+7)/6), m>=0} and are removed before taking partial sums to obtain the next row.
To generate the array, start with all 1's in row 0; from then on, obtain row n+1 from row n by first removing terms in row n at positions {floor(m*(m+7)/6), m>=0} and then taking partial sums.
For example, to generate row 2 from row 1:

Continuing in this way will generate all the rows of this array.
Amazingly, column 0 of this array = column 0 of triangle P=A136220:
where column k of P^3 = column 0 of P^(3k+3) such that column 0 of P^3 = column 0 of P shift one place left.
